text:
I grew up in a small, rural town in the Midwest, and my childhood was filled with simple things. We didn't have a lot of money, but my parents made sure I had everything I needed and some of the things I wanted. We had a few acres of land that we kept for a garden and a few animals. My siblings and I were often tasked with taking care of the animals, and I enjoyed that responsibility.

Growing up, I was an introverted child. I would often spend hours alone, reading and daydreaming. I had a vivid imagination, and I loved to explore the world around me. I had a strong sense of curiosity and was never afraid to ask questions or to seek out answers on my own. 

I was an agreeable child, and I didn't usually argue with my parents or siblings. I wanted to make everyone happy, and I was willing to do what was asked of me. I was also conscientious and always did my best to complete tasks as they were assigned. I had a strong sense of responsibility and was always eager to do the right thing.

I was emotionally stable as a child, and I rarely felt overwhelmed by emotions. I was able to handle difficult situations with a clear head. I was also open to experience, and I enjoyed exploring new things. I was creative and inventive, and I loved to come up with new ideas and projects.

As I grew older, I began to make more friends and became more outgoing. I was still introverted, but I was now more comfortable in social situations. I still had a strong sense of responsibility, and I was willing to help others whenever I could. I also had a strong sense of loyalty and trustworthiness, and I was always willing to lend a hand. 

My childhood was filled with simple moments of joy. I had a strong sense of appreciation for the small things in life, and I was never afraid to take risks or to explore my creativity. I was introverted, agreeable, conscientious, emotionally stable, and open to experience, and these traits have shaped me into the person I am today.
prompt:

Here are a number of characteristics that may or may not apply to you. For example, do you agree that you are someone who likes to spend time with others? Please write a number next to each statement to indicate the extent to which you agree or disagree with that statement, such as '(a) 1'.

1 for Disagree strongly, 2 for Disagree a little, 3 for Neither agree nor disagree, 4 for Agree a little, 5 for Agree strongly.
